description: A description of to how to produce and evaluate three-dimensional computerized forensic craniofacial reconstructions (CCFR) using Horos, Blender, Cloud Compare, MakeHuman and Picassa computer programs.
before_start:
You need download the software programs: Horos, Blender, MakeHuman, CloudCompare and Picasa.

You need a computed tomography (CT) of the skull of the alive person.
protocol_affiliation: Universidade Federal de São Paulo,Liverpool John Moores University,Universidade Federal de Uberlândia
manuscript_citation: Assessment of accuracy and recognition of three-dimensional computerized forensic craniofacial reconstruction
keywords: human identification, forensic dentistry, computer software applications, bioinformatics, forensic anthropology, 3D, facial depiction, facial reconstruction, CGI, CG, CT
authors: Geraldo Elias Miranda,Caroline Wilkinson,Mark Roughley,Thiago Leite Beaini,Rodolfo Francisco Haltenhoff Melani
status_info: We use this protocol in our group and it is working

components.data: DICOM files from computed tomography (CT) scans were reconstructed using the Horos program, a clinical imaging data viewer, to produce 3D sufaces of the subject's skin and skull .The files were saved and exported as .STL files.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: DICOM files from computed tomography (CT) scans were reconstructed using the Horos program, a clinical imaging data viewer, to produce 3D sufaces of the subject's skin and skull .The files were saved and exported as .STL files.

components.data: 1.	Generation of a 3D model of the skull using CT data.
components.name: Section

source_data.section: 1.	Generation of a 3D model of the skull using CT data.

components.data: 2.	Insert 3D model of the skull in Blender
components.name: Section

source_data.section: 2.	Insert 3D model of the skull in Blender

components.data: The generated STL file of the skull was imported into Blender. The 3D model of the skull was positioned in reference to the Frankfurt plane.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The generated STL file of the skull was imported into Blender. The 3D model of the skull was positioned in reference to the Frankfurt plane.

components.data: 3.	Position the pegs on the surface of the skull.
components.name: Section

source_data.section: 3.	Position the pegs on the surface of the skull.

components.data: The soft tissue markers (pegs) were placed perpendicularly over skull’s surface. We used soft tissue thickness from a study of a Brazilian sample that reports a table with male and female values for 10 mid-sagittal points and 11 bilateral points with in a total of 32 referenced landmarks. In this figure, for example, the menton peg is being placed.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The soft tissue markers (pegs) were placed perpendicularly over skull’s surface. We used soft tissue thickness from a study of a Brazilian sample that reports a table with male and female values for 10 mid-sagittal points and 11 bilateral points with in a total of 32 referenced landmarks. In this figure, for example, the menton peg is being placed.

components.data: 4.	Use pre-established parameters for placement of the eyes, nose and mouth.
components.name: Section

source_data.section: 4.	Use pre-established parameters for placement of the eyes, nose and mouth.

components.data:
The shape and position of the eyes, nose and mouth also followed pre-established parameters:

- Eyes: eyeballs of 24mm in diameters were placed inside the orbital cavity so that the eyeball and pupil were located within the orbits, 4 mm from the roof and 4-5 mm from the lateral wall. Eyeball protrusion was established as tangents from the margins of the orbital cavity crossing only the iris portion of the eye. The endocanthus of the eye, was placed 2 mm lateral to the lacrimal bone crest at its middle and the exocanthus approximately 3-4 mm medially from the malar tubercle.  For the CCFR’s, the eyelids were modeled closed as the CT exams of the subjects were performed in the same position.

- Nose: the maximum width of the piriform cavity represents approximately 3/5 of the maximum width of the nose. The tip of the nose was estimated to be at the crossing point of two lines: the nasal bone projection and a perpendicular line from the prosthion projection, in a 90º.

- Mouth: The inter-canine distance is estimated as 75% of the total mouth width. The height of the lips vermillion is 26% of the width. The lower and upper lip intersection should be placed in the lower section of the upper central incisor.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
The shape and position of the eyes, nose and mouth also followed pre-established parameters:

- Eyes: eyeballs of 24mm in diameters were placed inside the orbital cavity so that the eyeball and pupil were located within the orbits, 4 mm from the roof and 4-5 mm from the lateral wall. Eyeball protrusion was established as tangents from the margins of the orbital cavity crossing only the iris portion of the eye. The endocanthus of the eye, was placed 2 mm lateral to the lacrimal bone crest at its middle and the exocanthus approximately 3-4 mm medially from the malar tubercle.  For the CCFR’s, the eyelids were modeled closed as the CT exams of the subjects were performed in the same position.

- Nose: the maximum width of the piriform cavity represents approximately 3/5 of the maximum width of the nose. The tip of the nose was estimated to be at the crossing point of two lines: the nasal bone projection and a perpendicular line from the prosthion projection, in a 90º.

- Mouth: The inter-canine distance is estimated as 75% of the total mouth width. The height of the lips vermillion is 26% of the width. The lower and upper lip intersection should be placed in the lower section of the upper central incisor.

components.data: 5.	Choose an appropirate template from  the MakeHuman database
components.name: Section

source_data.section: 5.	Choose an appropirate template from  the MakeHuman database

components.data: In a forensic investigation, the anthropological examination will estimate the age, sex and ethnic group of the human remains. Using this information a 3D face model template (skin latyer) was selected as appropriate from the MakeHuman database.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: In a forensic investigation, the anthropological examination will estimate the age, sex and ethnic group of the human remains. Using this information a 3D face model template (skin latyer) was selected as appropriate from the MakeHuman database.

components.data: 6.	Import the chosen template 3D model (skin layer) from MakeHuman into Blender
components.name: Section

source_data.section: 6.	Import the chosen template 3D model (skin layer) from MakeHuman into Blender

components.data: The chosen 3D model (skin layer) template generated in MakeHuman was exported as an STL file and imported into Blender where it was placed over the skull model to be reconstructed. The 3D skin model template was altered to fit the skull.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The chosen 3D model (skin layer) template generated in MakeHuman was exported as an STL file and imported into Blender where it was placed over the skull model to be reconstructed. The 3D skin model template was altered to fit the skull.

components.data: 7.	Import the CCFR (computerized forensic craniofacial reconfruction) and the CT into CloudCompare
components.name: Section

source_data.section: 7.	Import the CCFR (computerized forensic craniofacial reconfruction) and the CT into CloudCompare

components.data: The CT skin 3D model was imported and placed as “reference” and the CCFR as “compared” and the software calculated the distances between the two point clouds. Sequentially, we used the “cut” tool to eliminate any lateral or lower parts that could be observed only in one of the models.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The CT skin 3D model was imported and placed as “reference” and the CCFR as “compared” and the software calculated the distances between the two point clouds. Sequentially, we used the “cut” tool to eliminate any lateral or lower parts that could be observed only in one of the models.

components.data: 8.	Import frontal facing photos of the individual, CT and CCFR into Picasa
components.name: Section

source_data.section: 8.	Import frontal facing photos of the individual, CT and CCFR into Picasa

components.data: In the field “people” in Picasa the standardized frontal facing photographs of each subject were inserted and named.  Frontal facial images captured from the CT soft-tissue model and from the CCFR were inserted into the database. Once the “people” field is calibrated by the imported images, the program can automatically scan existent ones. Consequently one of the four events occurs: 1- the image is not recognized as a face; 2 the image is recognized as a face but not a matching to any “people” (classified as unnamed); 3- the image is correlated to a known person and confirmation may be asked; 4- the image is incorrectly matched to the wrong person.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: In the field “people” in Picasa the standardized frontal facing photographs of each subject were inserted and named.  Frontal facial images captured from the CT soft-tissue model and from the CCFR were inserted into the database. Once the “people” field is calibrated by the imported images, the program can automatically scan existent ones. Consequently one of the four events occurs: 1- the image is not recognized as a face; 2 the image is recognized as a face but not a matching to any “people” (classified as unnamed); 3- the image is correlated to a known person and confirmation may be asked; 4- the image is incorrectly matched to the wrong person.
